Walk with Arwen some more
'The gift for Lady Arwen has been found, [placeholder]. Lady Galadriel herself holds it and awaits your arrival. Though it is Glorfindel's betrothal gift, the honour is yours to deliver it.'
Accept the honour of delivering Glorfindel's betrothal gift to Arwen.
Talk to Arwen
'DNT - Blah!'

'An age is ending, [placeholder]. Can you feel it? Can you feel the calling of the sea? True, it is not ended yet, and in the counting of Men and dwarves, it will not be over for some modest span to come. But we, [placeholder], may look back and remember, may we not? I remember the years upon years before my heart was given, moving freely from Imladris to Lorien, from Lorien to Imladris, like a carefree minnow between pond and stream. Then to know that nothing shall be as it was.

'Do you know what these flowers are, [placeholder]? They are lovers' tokens, and they are wrought with uncommon skill so that a sympathy exists between them, as if they were tied by an unseen thread no matter the distance. If anything should befall the owner of one flower - should they grow ill or die - then the other's flower will wilt, wither, and crumble. Thus may my Aragorn always know that I am well and whole, and I may know the same of him.

'It is at once a great comfort and a constant reminder of our doom and of endings-to-be.'
You should ask Lady Galadriel in the Court of Lothlórien for Arwen's gift.
DNT walk over there

'A true gift is one which sings of the receiver in the voice of the giver, it is said. By that mark, Glorfindel has chosen the truest of gifts.'

Lady Galadriel produces two exquisite flowers, and only after a moment do you perceive that they are brooches, wrought of silver filament, green and violet silk, and finest cloth-of-gold, and not real flowers at all. She returns them to a silken box, which she hands to you.

'Take these to Arwen, [placeholder]. She will tell you something of what they mean to her, if she wishes.'

Speaking the traditional words of a gift-giver in the Elven tongue, you present the gift to Arwen. She opens the silken box and you complete the formal speech, indicating that the flowers are from Glorfindel.\n\nI know then what these are and what is their meaning. It is a good and a beautiful thought Glorfindel has given me in this gift. Come, [placeholder]. Walk with me a spell.'
DNT Here, this is the gift Glorfindel wished you to bring. It is a subtle, thoughtful gift.

'Indeed, I have tarried in Rivendell some of years now, though it is not counted overlong by the reckoning of our people, [placeholder]. These last tens of years, I have lived here in anticipation of a promise, waiting to learn if fortune should decree it held or broken. That brief time has been both as an eternity and a single breath to me.

'Shortly, we shall set forth for Gondor, as you know, and shortly thereafter, when we reach that land, I shall become one with the treasure of my heart. He will be king and I queen. Like Lúthien and Beren, whose love and tale is etched upon our hearts. Much gained, yes, and much lost.

'Come, let us go farther down the path.'

'Much will come to pass, [placeholder]. It will come soon, swift as a diving hawk. Swift as the sun's last descent into night. Much will be gained, and much, too, lost.'

Arwen laughs, softly, sweetly, and a little sadly.

'You are thinking, I am sure, that much has already happened since first your journey began. Nor are you mistaken! You have seen much, but soon all Middle-earth shall see more. And while you have been through many lands and among many peoples, I have been here and among only my own.

'To the left now, where that statue stands.'
Walk with Arwen a little further
Arwen has asked you to walk with her in Imlad Gelair in Rivendell. If you get separated, ring the bell.\n\nGo with Arwen to the left past the bridge, where the statue stands.
The air is sweet and clear, this Elven retreat fine to behold

'I am going off to dwell in the lands of Men, and I shall become as they who dwell there, [placeholder]. I will gain my heart's desire and I will be Queen of the heirs of Númenor, at the dawn of a new age. But I will lose the home I have known. I will lose so many faces dearest to me, who I leave behind and who themselves will make even greater journeys, soon enough. I will lose the roots-deep certainty of days unending. Where I go, days will be numbered, and so also lives.'

Arwen stops and meets your gaze with level eyes that are filled with many things.

'I thank you for walking with me, [placeholder]. I thank you for listening kindly and without judgment. Sadness and joy are like two streams joined into a river, and the finest of Elven weavers could not part them now. But I have a journey to prepare for, and time will not tarry.

'I will see you in Gondor, friend? I hope that I do. I should like that very much!'

'Come, let us go farther down the path.'

'An age is ending, [placeholder]. It is not ended quite yet, and in the counting of Men and Dwarves, and, yes, Hobbits, it will not be over for some modest span to come. But for me, to have known centuries... centuries before my heart was given, moving freely from Imladris to Lorien, from Lorien to Imladris, like a carefree minnow between pond and stream. Then to know that nothing shall be as it was.

Thus may my Aragorn always know that I am well and whole, and I may know the same of him.

'It is at once a great comfort and a constant reminder of our doom and of endings-to-be.'
